import pandas as pd
df = pd.read_csv('../input/properties-data-dubai/properties_data.csv')
df.head(10)
#View first 10 data rows
source.c3499342:
df.describe()
#the data Well discrabied, the maximums, the minimums, the meam and etc
source.a4345bea:
#With the info command it will show the type of each column includes.
df.info()
source.2198295e:
format_dict = {'price':'${0:,.2f}', 'id':'{:%m-%Y}', 'no_of_bedrooms':'{:.2%}'}
#We make sure that the Month column has datetime format
df['id'] = pd.to_datetime(df['id'])
#We apply the style to the visualization
df.head().style.format(format_dict)
source.136dcf51:
#We can highlight maximum and minimum values with colours.
format_dict = {'id':'{:%m-%Y}'} #Simplified format dictionary with values that do make sense for our data
df.head().style.format(format_dict).highlight_max(color='green').highlight_min(color='#ff0000')
source.a6b61670:
#We use a color gradient to display the data values
df.head(10).style.format(format_dict).background_gradient(subset=['price', 'size_in_sqft'], cmap='BuGn')
source.d357bfca:
#We can also display the data values with bars
df.head().style.format(format_dict).bar(color='red', subset=['price_per_sqft', 'price'])
source.4e828739:
#we also can combine the above functions and generate a more complex visualization.
df.head(10).style.format(format_dict).background_gradient(subset=['price', 'no_of_bedrooms'], cmap='BuGn').highlight_max(color='yellow')
source.ceeee7a4:
from pandas_profiling import ProfileReport
prof = ProfileReport(df)
prof.to_file(output_file='report.html')
output_file
source.fdc35dde:
#Matplotlib is the most basic library for visualizing data graphically.
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.plot(df['no_of_bedrooms'], df['no_of_bathrooms'], label='no_of_bathrooms') 
#The parameter label is to indicate the legend. This doesn't mean that it will be shown, we'll have to use another command.
source.75c16241:
#t is not very clear which variable each color represents. We’re going to improve the chart by adding a legend and titles.
plt.plot(df['quality'], df['no_of_bedrooms'], label='no_of_bedrooms')
plt.plot(df['quality'], df['maid_room'], label='maid_room')
plt.plot(df['quality'], df['no_of_bathrooms'], label='no_of_bathrooms')
plt.xlabel('quality')
plt.ylabel('-')
plt.title('Properties in DUBAI')
plt.grid(True)
plt.legend()
source.9a5f1863:
#make the graphs of multiple variables in the same graph and thus compare them.
plt.plot(df['quality'], df['no_of_bedrooms'], label='no_of_bedrooms')
plt.plot(df['quality'], df['maid_room'], label='maid_room')
plt.plot(df['quality'], df['no_of_bathrooms'], label='no_of_bathrooms')
source.5eff9098:
fig, axes = plt.subplots(2,2)
axes[0, 0].hist(df['price'])
axes[0, 1].scatter(df['id'], df['price'])
axes[1, 0].plot(df['id'], df['no_of_bedrooms'])
axes[1, 1].plot(df['id'], df['size_in_sqft'])
source.96fb05b8:
plt.plot(df['price'], df['size_in_sqft'], 'r-')
plt.plot(df['price'], df['size_in_sqft']*2, 'bs')
plt.plot(df['price'], df['size_in_sqft']*3, 'g^')
source.1cbfc38d:
#drawing the graph with different styles for the points of each variable:
plt.plot(df['price'], df['size_in_sqft'], 'r-')
plt.plot(df['price'], df['size_in_sqft'], 'bs')
plt.plot(df['price'], df['size_in_sqft'], 'g^')
source.916937b6:
#Seaborn is a library based on Matplotlib.
import seaborn as sns
sns.set()
sns.scatterplot(df['quality'], df['price'])
source.e8c89ae3:
import seaborn as sns
sns.set()
sns.scatterplot(df['size_in_sqft'], df['price'])
source.5c4be1bc:
# informative graph is the jointplot that allows us to see a scatterplot together with a histogram of the two variables and see how they are distributed
sns.jointplot(x='price', y='size_in_sqft', data=df)
source.e646f55f:
fig, axes = plt.subplots(1, 2, sharey=True, figsize=(8, 4))
sns.scatterplot(x="quality", y="price", hue="balcony", data=df, ax=axes[0])
axes[0].set_title('price')
sns.scatterplot(x="quality", y="size_in_sqft", hue="balcony", data=df, ax=axes[1])
axes[1].set_title('size_in_sqft')
source.deeacdea:
#Bokeh 
#Bokeh is a library that allows you to generate interactive graphics. We can export them to an HTML document that we can share with anyone who has a web browse
from bokeh.plotting import figure, output_file, save
output_file('data.html')
source.b33807f1:
p = figure(title='Dubai properties', x_axis_label='size_in_sqft', y_axis_label='price')
p.line(df['size_in_sqft'], df['price'], legend='popularity', line_width=2)
save(p)
